summary: This is the First Amended Complaint filed by the Government of the United States Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein, its executors, and a network of Virgin Islands corporate entities. It alleges that Epstein and his associates operated a criminal sex trafficking enterprise in the Virgin Islands, using a complex web of companies to own properties and assets that facilitated and concealed the abuse of young women and underage girls. The complaint seeks damages and outlines the structure of the 'Epstein Enterprise.' This document is a portion of the First Amended Complaint filed by the Government of the Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein. It details the use of Epstein's private islands (Little St. James and Great St. James) as secluded locations for sex trafficking and abuse, the creation of corporate entities to conceal assets and activities, fraudulent acquisition of tax benefits, and ongoing efforts to obstruct law enforcement and environmental inspections. This document is a section of the First Amended Complaint filed by the Government of the Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein and other Defendants. It details Counts Three through Fourteen, which allege violations of the Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO) related to human trafficking, forced labor, sexual servitude, child abuse, and rape. The complaint describes the 'Epstein Enterprise' as an illicit organization engaged in a pattern of criminal activity. This document is a segment of the First Amended Complaint filed by the Government of the Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein and other defendants. It details multiple counts under the Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organization Act (CICO), alleging a wide-ranging criminal enterprise involving human trafficking, forced labor, sexual servitude, prostitution, fraudulent conveyance, and fraudulent claims for tax incentives. The complaint describes the use of Epstein's properties and corporate entities to facilitate and conceal these crimes. This is a First Amended Complaint filed by the Government of the Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein and related entities. It details allegations of a criminal enterprise involving human trafficking, sexual abuse, and other offenses, and seeks extensive civil remedies including forfeiture of property, punitive damages, and dissolution of the enterprise.

events.title: Epstein Acquires Little St. James
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein acquired the private island of Little St. James in the Virgin Islands.

events.title: Epstein Registers as Sex Offender in Virgin Islands
events.description: Epstein registered as a Tier I sex offender in the Virgin Islands following his Florida conviction, requiring annual registration and travel notifications.

events.title: Epstein Purchases Great St. James
events.description: Epstein purchased the neighboring island of Great St. James, allegedly to further shield his criminal activities on Little St. James.

events.title: Epstein Found Dead in Custody
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead while in custody in New York on federal sex crime charges.

events.title: Estate Files Probate Petition
events.description: Defendants Indyke and Kahn filed a Petition for Probate and Letters Testamentary for Epstein's estate in the Virgin Islands Superior Court.

events.title: Epstein Enterprise Trafficking Operation
events.description: The complaint alleges a pattern of criminal activity from 2001 to 2019 where the Epstein Enterprise trafficked, sexually abused, and held captive underage girls and young women at Virgin Islands properties.

events.title: Acquisition of Little St. James
events.description: The Epstein Enterprise acquired Little St. James island, described as a secluded hideaway used for trafficking and sexually abusing young women and underage girls.

events.title: Acquisition of Great St. James
events.description: The Epstein Enterprise, using a straw purchaser, acquired Great St. James island for over $20 million to prevent surveillance of activities on Little St. James and create barriers to escape.

events.title: EDC Hearing for Tax Incentives
events.description: Epstein and his attorney Ericka Kellerhals gave sworn testimony to the Economic Development Commission, falsely describing Southern Trust Company's business to secure a 10-year tax exemption package.

events.title: Sex Offender Verification Refusal
events.description: Epstein refused to allow Virgin Islands investigators and U.S. Marshals onto Little St. James for a sex offender registration verification, meeting them only at his St. Thomas office.

events.title: Misleading Travel Notification
events.description: Epstein notified authorities of travel to France but was later found to have also traveled to Vienna and Monaco, misleading the government about his movements.

events.title: Estate Files Motion for Claims Program
events.description: Epstein's Estate filed a motion to establish a voluntary claims resolution program that would impose confidentiality and require claimants to sacrifice other claims, seen as an effort to conceal criminal activities.

events.title: Epstein's Unreported Foreign Travel
events.description: Epstein traveled to Vienna and Monaco on at least two occasions without disclosing the travel to the Virgin Islands sex offender registry as required by law.

events.title: Pre-Death Asset Transfer to The 1953 Trust
events.description: Days before his death, Epstein transferred significant assets, including assets held by other defendants, into The 1953 Trust in an alleged effort to defeat creditor claims and avoid probate court oversight.

events.title: Filing of First Amended Complaint
events.description: The Government of the Virgin Islands files its First Amended Complaint against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein, formally alleging a pattern of criminal activity and seeking civil remedies under the Virgin Islands Code.

keyFacts: The Government of the Virgin Islands alleges Jeffrey Epstein operated a criminal sex trafficking 'Enterprise' from his private islands, Little St. James and Great St. James, using a network of Virgin Islands corporate entities to facilitate and conceal the abuse.
Epstein's estate, valued at over $577 million in Virgin Islands assets, and The 1953 Trust, amended two days before his death, are named as defendants and held responsible for damages.

Specific corporate defendants include Nautilus, Inc. (owns Little St. James), Great St. Jim, LLC (owns Great St. James), Plan D, LLC and Hyperion Air, LLC (own aircraft used for trafficking), and Southern Trust Company, Inc. (a financial entity with hundreds of millions in assets).

The complaint details methods of the Enterprise, including luring victims with promises of modeling careers, using coded language ('work' for sexual abuse), paying victims to recruit others, and using coercion like passport confiscation to maintain control.

Epstein's associates, including his executors Darren Indyke and Richard Kahn, are alleged to have knowingly facilitated and concealed the criminal activity through their roles in the corporate entities.

Epstein's private islands, Little St. James (acquired 1998) and Great St. James (acquired 2016), were used as secluded locations to traffic, harbor, and sexually abuse young women and underage girls for nearly two decades.

The Epstein Enterprise created a complex network of Virgin Islands corporate entities (e.g., Southern Trust Company) to conceal assets, fund criminal activities, and fraudulently obtain millions in tax exemptions by misrepresenting their business.

Epstein and his associates actively obstructed law enforcement and regulatory oversight, including refusing sex offender verification inspections, misleading authorities about travel, and preventing environmental inspections of illegal construction.

Employees of the enterprise were required to sign confidentiality agreements prohibiting cooperation with law enforcement and were directed not to interact with or disclose information about guests on the islands.

The complaint alleges the enterprise's conduct violated multiple Virgin Islands laws, including human trafficking, child abuse, and racketeering (CICO) statutes, and seeks civil penalties, damages, and forfeiture of properties used in the crimes.
The complaint formally defines and accuses the 'Epstein Enterprise' of being an illicit criminal organization under the Virgin Islands' Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO).
Specific criminal acts alleged include human trafficking for forced labor and sexual servitude, child abuse and neglect, aggravated rape, and second-degree rape.

The complaint alleges a conspiracy where Defendants recruited young women and underage girls under false pretenses (e.g., modeling opportunities) to travel to the Virgin Islands to engage in sexual acts with Epstein and others, often in exchange for money, gifts, or scholarships.
The Defendants are accused of knowingly benefiting financially and otherwise from their participation in the criminal enterprise.
The document is structured as a legal complaint listing multiple counts (3-14) with detailed allegations, indicating a broad and systematic prosecution strategy by the Virgin Islands government.

The complaint alleges the 'Epstein Enterprise' was a criminal organization whose primary purposes were human trafficking, forced labor, and sexual servitude, violating the Virgin Islands' CICO statute.
Epstein's property on Little St. James is described as being used as a hub for prostitution and sexual activity, including with minors, with the Enterprise facilitating travel to the location.
Epstein failed to report international travel to Vienna and Monaco to the Virgin Islands sex offender registry, constituting separate violations.
Days before his death, Epstein allegedly transferred significant assets into 'The 1953 Trust' in a fraudulent conveyance intended to hinder creditors and the probate court.

The Epstein Enterprise allegedly used the Southern Trust Company, Inc. to fraudulently obtain valuable tax incentives from the Virgin Islands government by misrepresenting its business activities, and used the company to pay and conceal the activities of participants in the criminal enterprise.
The Government of the Virgin Islands is seeking punitive damages against Epstein's estate, citing intentional and outrageous conduct that 'shocks the conscience'.

The complaint seeks forfeiture of all Epstein's interests in Virgin Islands property used to facilitate the criminal enterprise, specifically naming Little St. James Island and Greater St. James Island.
The Government demands the dissolution of the 'Epstein Enterprise' and the revocation of any licenses, permits, and tax benefits granted to the defendants.
The legal action is based on the Virgin Islands Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO), seeking treble damages, civil penalties, and disgorgement of ill-gotten gains.
The document is a formal court filing (Case 1:15-cv-07433-LAP Document 1111-1) dated February 5, 2020, submitted by Attorney General Enis N. George.
